ygData.subject: Re: [archive-crawler] Regex to strip '$' from url where directory name includes $
ygData.msgSnippet: Heritrix URI canonicalization only affects the form of the URI used to determine if the URI has been already-scheduled. It does not change the form of the URI

Subject: Re: [archive-crawler] Regex to strip '$' from url where directory
 name includes $
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=137285340; y=mknRflNPcLnnhU4kG6Q62ss5jd8fplvkKQB-xxlVLaXr
X-Yahoo-Profile: gojomo

Heritrix URI canonicalization only affects the form of the URI used to 
determine if the URI has been already-scheduled. It does not change the 
form of the URI visited or recorded in any log or written output.

So, once "http://hello/i/$am/here/" is scheduled, if your 
canonicalization is properly stripping the '$', then it will prevent any 
other URIs that canonicalize the same way from being scheduled in the 
future. For example, since "http://hello/i/am/here/" and 
"http://hello/i/am/$here/" would both canonicalize the same way, neither 
would pass already-scheduled testing in the future.

Also, I don't believe the {} brackets are needed for backreferences in 
the replacement-format string.

- Gordon @ IA

mjjjhjemj wrote:
> I am using the following uri-canonicalization-rules in my crawl:
> --> RegexRule
> enabled: true
> matching-regex: ^(.+)(?:\/\$)(.*)$
> format: ${1}${2}
> 
> Where as I know "^(.+)(?:\/\$)(.*)$" is not quite what I want since
> this should remove the leading "/" for file directories that start
> with "/$", but this does not even do as I expected:
> expected output given http://hello/i/$am/here/...
> should be http://hello/iam/here/...
> It is not doing anything.
> 
> My goal is if heritrix finds:
> http://hello/i/$am/here/...
> 
> to change it to:
> http://hello/i/am/here/...
> 
> both in the reference in the text of all files captured and the
> filenames of the files captured.
> 
> Any help would be appreciated,
> Mike
